title: 'Life-changing' pay rise could be coming for Uber Eats, DoorDash workers
text:
A landmark ﻿deal inked between the union and two of Australia's biggest food delivery services could see pay rates soar for gig economy workers.

Uber Eats and DoorDash have struck a deal with the Transport Workers Union (TWU) ﻿for a set of minimum standards for delivery drivers and riders.

The agreement includes a minimum "safety net pay" rate, dispute resolution processes, accident insurance and legal representation rights.

Uber Eats and DoorDash have struck a deal with the Transport Workers Union (TWU). (Paul Rovere)

﻿The deal would provide wage stability for delivery workers who are often paid below Australia's minimum wage due to being paid per delivery rather than hours worked.

The draft standards submitted to the Fair Work Commission noted a $32-an-hour safety net pay rate, according to the Australian Financial Review .

This would result in a 25 per cent pay rise for Uber Eats and DoorDash workers.

If approved, the new standards would come into effect from July next year.

It follows﻿ several years of union campaigning and negotiations between TWU and the two delivery services.

"Gig workers have campaigned for years for a better industry and for the first time in the world, there could soon be a minimum floor that represents a life-changing increase to their pay," said TWU National Secretary Michale Kaine.

"After constructive discussions with Uber Eats and DoorDash, this is a significant step towards a fairer gig economy.

"We look forward to the Fair Work Commission considering these new standards and working towards a strong foundation for fairness in the gig economy."

Australian gig economy workers could receive a major pay rise under the reforms. (AP)

Both Uber Eats and DoorDash supported the proposal.

﻿DoorDash APAC Vice President Simon Rossi said it is important that working standards in the on-demand economy continue to "evolve".

"Delivery workers keep Australia moving, helping busy households and supporting small businesses," Rossi said.

"This proposal shows we can work together to lift standards and still enable the flexibility people rely on, under the Government's new laws."

Uber Eats Australia and New Zealand Managing Director Ed Kitchen added that the service supports "sensible and modern reforms".

"We believe fair standards and flexibility should not be mutually exclusive," Kitchen said.

"They are both essential to ensuring gig work continues to meet the expectations of Australians and reflects the important role delivery people play in their communities."

The food delivery economy in Australia has long been tumultuous for operators.

Menulog, Foodora and Deliveroo have all pulled out of the local market in recent years, citing tough trading conditions.

title: 'Extraordinary boom': Homes less affordable than ever for Aussies
text:
Homes are less affordable than ever in Australia﻿, as prices drift out of reach and the burden on mortgage-holders gets heavier.

A new report from Cotality showed the price-to-income ratio, the years required to save a deposit, and the share of income needed to rent, all hit record highs in 2025, leaving both buyers and renters struggling.﻿

Despite recent interest rate cuts, the cost of servicing a new loan remains high, requiring about 45 per cent of median household income.

Housing is less affordable than ever - whether buying or renting. (Getty)

Saving a standard 20 per cent deposit takes 12 years as a national average, and more than a decade in Sydney, Adelaide, Brisbane, and Perth.

Tenants are also now dedicating a record 33.4 per cent of their income to rent, well in excess of the 20-year average.﻿

Affordability has deteriorated most sharply for houses, which now, on average, are valued at 8.9 times the average income, up from 6.6 five years ago.

And a flight to regional areas is less afford﻿able than ever too, with homes outside the capitals valued at 8.1 times the annual average income, compared to 8.2 for cities.

Sydney continues to lead the pack as the most expensive and unaffordable city, while conditions are deteriorating across Adelaide, Brisbane, and Perth.

Some mild improvements in affordability have been seen in Canberra, Hobart, and Melbourne, while Darwin is the most affordable capital to buy in.

The Northern Territory is the only major region where less than 30 per cent of income is required to service a new mortgage.

Cotality head of research Eliza Owen said a confluence of factors over the pandemic and post-pandemic period years had driven a major deterioration in housing affordability.

"Australian home values have climbed roughly 47.3 per cent since March 2020, an extraordinary rise that added about $280,000 to the median dwelling value," he said.

Supply has been low while demand has been high. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"This surge was fuelled by pandemic-era monetary stimulus and record-low interest rates that supercharged borrowing capacity and demand, even as housing supply lagged well behind household formation."

She said there was also low housing supply, with multiple issues including construction sector insolvencies, rising material costs, and planning bottlenecks all restricting new housing projects.

"In short, the past five years combined extraordinary demand drivers with supply constraints, creating an extraordinary boom in both home values and rents," Owen said.

title: Labor MP goes rogue in call to end 'profiteering' by gas exporters
text:
A﻿ rebel federal Labor MP has joined calls for gas exporters to be compelled to sell cheaper fuel for Australian use to help drive down energy prices.

In a parliamentary speech yesterday, Ed Husic, slammed exporters for "profiteering" by putting overseas customers ahead of Australians to gain commercial success.

He broke ranks with Labor by supporting a motion from independent MP Nicolette Boele which urged the government to "only allow uncontracted gas to be exported after it has been offered to the domestic market at a reasonable price". ﻿

Labor Ed Husic has joined calls for a shake-up in Australia's gas market. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Three-quarters of the liquefied natural gas (LNG) produced in Australia heads overseas, and the energy watchdog forecasts supplies will run low in eastern states by mid-2028.

Husic said the gas market was "fundamentally distorted" and bold action was needed to ensure Australian households and businesses paid a fair and stable price.

"Our gas, our prices: that should be the bedrock of our thinking," he said.

"The cost of doing business in this country for multinational gas firms is that they must provide a gas price in line with historic pre-pandemic levels, and this should apply to any new field that's opened too.

"We need strong action; a complete rethink of the terms on which Australian resources serve the Australian national interest." ﻿

Australia is the world's biggest exporter of liquefied natural gas. (Michelle Mossop/AFR)

In some eastern states, gas prices since the pandemic have risen from about $3 per gigajoule to more than $10 today.

The Albanese government in 2022 stepped in to cap gas prices at $12 per gigajoule in Australia for a 12-month period. ﻿

Boele's motion called for a shake-up in gas exporting regulations.

Uncontracted gas would initially have to be offered to the Australian market at a ﻿"reasonable price" before it could be sold overseas, under her plan.

Her push for change comes amid a report today by the Institute of Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA), which says the Australian gas sector is "broken".

Its study takes issue with industry claims that the path to cheaper domestic prices can only come from developing more gas fields.

But the IEEFA study said "the cheapest way to supply Australian gas consumers is instead to redirect small amounts of uncontracted LNG from exports to the domestic market".﻿

title: Why the crypto market is crashing
text:
Even by crypto standards, it's been a rough few weeks.

Investors in digital assets are accustomed to extreme volatility, but a US$1 trillion ($1.55 trillion) wipeout over the past six weeks has tested even crypto's diehard believers and alienated many of its newest converts.

Bitcoin, the industry bellwether, has fallen dramatically since early October, when it hit a record high of US$126,000 ($194,895).

Bitcoin is struggling in a volatile crypto market. (CNN)

The world's most popular cryptocurrency dipped below US$81,000 ($125,290) on Friday before recovering slightly over the weekend.

On Monday, as the broader stock market rallied, bitcoin topped US$88,000 ($136,117), rising nearly 2 per cent over a 24-hour period. (Crypto markets are open 24 hours a day, seven days a week.)

It is shaping up to be one of crypto's worst months on record, and it's not clear the market has bottomed out.

"Whether Bitcoin stabilises after this correction remains uncertain," Deutsche Bank analysts wrote.

The broader stock market has rallied. (Bloomberg)

"Unlike prior crashes, driven primarily by retail speculation, this year's downturn has occurred amid substantial institutional participation, policy developments, and global macro trends."

While crypto's fate has broadly mirrored the stock market's in recent years, its current angst runs deeper. That's largely thanks to an influx of mainstream money that behaves very differently from the funds controlled by a typical crypto investor.

Bitcoin is in a bear market, having dropped 30 per cent from its most recent high, while the S&P 500 is down just 3 per cent from its most recent peak. It is on track for its worst month since the 2022 crypto "winter" that culminated in the collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried's FTX.

Much hangs over the Federal Reserve's next rate cut. (AP Photo/J Scott Applewhite, File)

Anxiety is coursing through stocks and crypto for two key reasons: Investors are fretting over the Federal Reserve's next rate cut, and they're worrying about whether AI is a bubble that'll blow up in their faces.

All of that weighs on crypto traders because digital assets, like tech stocks, are especially sensitive to changes in the Fed's benchmark rate, which affects the cost of borrowing money and can quickly sap investor appetite for risk.

But crypto investors have an additional hangover to deal with following an October 10 flash crash.

Trump's trade war with China prompted many to get out of the crypto market. (AP)

When US President Donald Trump reignited his trade war with China that day, it prompted a wave of panic-selling that triggered automatic liquidations across the highly leveraged crypto market.

In a single day, the flash crash wiped out US$19 billion ($29.4 billion) worth of crypto. For a lot of folks, the stomach-churning crash was all the motivation they needed to exit crypto completely, and that's left bitcoin and other tokens more susceptible to volatility.

The flash crash forced many investors sell their holdings to meet margin calls. That tends to have a snowball effect: The more bitcoin falls, the more calls investors face from their brokerages, the more they have to sell their bitcoin (and other holdings) to cover their positions.

What makes this crypto crash different is the presence of billions of dollars that have entered the crypto market through spot bitcoin funds that US regulators approved last year.

Mainstream investors got into crypto to enjoy the ride up, but they don't have the same level of devotion to the ideology as early adopters who are bolstered by intense online communities encouraging one another to buy the dip and keep the faith.

"The bottom line is, bitcoin is for normies now," Steve Sosnick, chief strategist at Interactive Brokers, said.

"As a result, the normies are going to view it as another speculative holding in their portfolio … it's going to be treated like a volatile mainstream investment."

title: BOM asked to explain why new website cost $92 million more than reported
text:
The federal government has asked the Bureau of ﻿Meteorology to explain why the total bill for their unpopular new website cost $92 million more than the agency previously stated.

The Bureau's new chief, Stuart Minchin, yesterday revealed that the project had cost $96.5 million rather than $4.1 million, which was only the cost of redesigning the front-end of the website.

The total figure includes ﻿a $78 million contract for Accenture Australia.

READ MORE: ﻿ Snapchat to ask users to prove their age ahead of social media ban

Environment Minister Murray Watt ﻿was not happy to learn of the cost blowout. (Alex Ellinghausen)

"The remaining cost reflects the significant investment required to fully rebuild and test the systems and technology that underpin the website, making sure it is secure and stable and can draw in the huge amounts of data gathered from our observing network and weather models," Minchin said in a statement.

Environment Minister Murray Watt, who oversees the Bureau of Meteorology, today said he was "not happy" to learn of the blowout.

"The initial figure that the BoM provided in the range of $4 million was for one aspect of the website development," he told ABC.

"It's a matter for them why they chose to provide that figure rather than a broader figure.

"But there's no doubt that there have been increases in the cost of this website as it's been developed, and one of the things I have asked the new CEO of the BoM to get on top of is what happened here."

Watt has met with Minchin twice since he took on the Bureau's top role a fortnight ago, first to raise concerns about criticisms of the new website and a second ﻿time to discuss the total cost figures.

"I'm looking forward to a bit of a change in the culture and the approach of the BoM," he said, throwing his support behind Minchin to "get on top of this and drive some change".

"If there are lessons around future procurements that are needed, then we need to know what they are."

The federal government has asked the Bureau of ﻿Meteorology to explain why the total bill for their unpopular new website cost $92 million more than the agency previously stated. (Bureau of Meteorology)

The Bureau of Meteorology's website, which is one of the most visited sites in Australia, was last upgraded under Kevin Rudd's first term as prime minister and found to have vulnerabilities after a cyber intrusion in 2015.

The redesigned website went live on October 22 under former chief Andrew Johnson and was met with heavy criticism over usability issues, including difficulties finding features, and complaints about the rain radar and weather map.

The federal government ordered the Bureau of Meteorology to fix the website, with some changes already made.

﻿Minchin said a website update was scheduled to go live last week, but was postponed due to the severe Tropical Cyclone Fina off the Northern Territory coast.

The update will respond directly to community feedback received during the beta phase, with a focus on making the rain radar and weather map easier to use.

It will also include video tutorials, website help and troubleshooting to help users navigate the site. ﻿

READ MORE: ﻿ Milestone shifts in Aussie drinking habits revealed

Dr Stuart Minchin, new chief executive of the Bureau of Meteorology. (Alex Ellinghausen)

"Given this [$96.5 million] investment, it's vital we get it right," he said in a statement.

"I want to assure you that our dedicated teams are working hard to continue delivering website updates and improvements as quickly as possible."

The Bureau of Meteorology's new website update will be rescheduled as soon as the severe weather subsides, with a date to be announced soon. ﻿

title: Regional Queensland among least affordable for renters across country
text:
Regional Queensland has the most unaffordable rental market of the regions nationally, with even average earners being pushed into rental stress, paying more than 30 per cent of their income in rent, according to new data.

The annual Rental Affordability Index (RAI) report reveals median rent in the regions is now soaring above Brisbane, despite ﻿those areas typically having lower household incomes.

Affordability is worst along the south-east coast, where the Gold Coast, Sunshine Coast and surrounding areas are classed as Unaffordable to Severely Unaffordable.

READ MORE: Fina strengthens to category 4 on path to Western Australia ﻿

The Sunshine Coast is one of the least affordable regions in Queensland. (Getty)

A single pensioner living in regional Queensland would be required to pay ﻿61 per cent of their income in rent, the report showed.﻿

The situation is even more dire for single working parents, single people living on welfare﻿ and even full-time workers on minimum wage.

Perth, Sydney and regional New South Wales are also among the least affordable parts of the country.

While rents are stabilising in some cities, they are still considered unaffordable, with the exception of Canberra.﻿

Ellen Witte, Principal and Partner at SGS Economics and Planning and the lead author of the report, said rental prices are only stabilising in the cities because renters cannot absorb any further rent increases.

"We have finally seen affordability stabilise in many places after rapid declines to record low levels since 2021," she said.

"The stabilisation may have less to do with relief and more to do with renters reaching their limit and being unable to pay more, combined with some easing of housing supply constraints."

Robert Pradolin, Founder and Executive Director of Housing All Australians warned key workers across the country are being priced out of living close to their jobs, putting community services under strain.

"Housing that people can afford is critical economic infrastructure, and without it, our national prosperity and productivity are being held back," Pradolin said.

title: Kyrgios's Australian Open wildcard bid heats up with Kooyong entry
text:
Nick Kyrgios will contest the returning Kooyong Classic in Melbourne as the former Wimbledon finalist continues his surprise bid to make a competitive comeback at the Australian Open.

Kyrgios has added the January 13-15 round-robin to a packed schedule also featuring exhibition matches next month in the US against Ben Shelton and Tommy Paul, before a much-hyped "Battle of the Sexes" showdown in Dubai on December 28 against women's world number one Aryna Sabalenka.

The Australian has not played on the ATP Tour since March, with career-threatening knee and wrist surgeries restricting the one-time world number 13 to just six matches in more than three years.

But the mercurial talent revealed to AAP this month that he was hoping to play the Brisbane International and then the Australian Open if his body survived his succession of exhibition matches.

The 30-year-old said he had been training like he was during his career-best year in 2022, when he lost the Wimbledon final to Novak Djokovic in four sets, then reached the US Open quarter-finals.

"I don't know whether to call it a miracle or anything, but my knee feels like it's gotten younger by a couple of years," Kyrgios said.

"I really didn't have hope to be able to play AO or just ever get back to that point of where I felt comfortable and competing and really letting my body go.

"But something in the last month, I don't know what it is. I was with my masseuse and physio last night and something really has changed with my knee.

"Like, it's not swelling. It's not feeling bad after a session."

Having spiralled to the devil's number of 666 in the world since his lay-off, Kyrgios would need a wildcard entry into any tournaments over the Australian summer.

Kyrgios wary of Sabalenka for Batlle of the Sexes clash Nick Kyrgios insists he won't be taking Aryna Sabalenka lightly but nor is he ready to be rolled by the women's world number-one in their Battle of the Sexes clash.

The ATP told AAP his injury-protected ranking of world number 21 — which afforded him direct entry to certain events — expired on November 10.

As a former winner in Brisbane and perennial fan favourite and 2022 Australian Open doubles champion, Kyrgios's wildcard cases would appear compelling.

His inclusion at Kooyong — which was not held last year — follows the announcement that newly crowned Italian Davis Cup heroes Flavio Cobolli, the world number 22, and Matteo Berrettini, another ex-Wimbledon runner-up, would also feature.

Other stars include Italy's world number eight Lorenzo Musetti, the 11th-ranked Alexander Bublik and former Australian Open finalist Marin Cilic.

The Australian Open starts on January 18.

AAP

title: How Riddell's rise to become AFLW's best mirrors Kangaroos' dominance
text:
It's wild now to think Ash Riddell was overlooked in not one but two AFLW drafts at the beginning of the competition.

There were only eight teams at that stage, yet she was the only player named in the 2017 VFLW Team of the Year to not be drafted.

Kangaroos star Ash Riddell wins AFLW best and fairest Runner-up to Adelaide's Ebony Marinoff last year, Riddell polled 23 votes to add the league's highest individual honour to her fifth All-Australian selection.

North Melbourne picked her up as a free agent during the club's signing period of the 2018 AFL Women's draft when the Kangaroos, along with Geelong, came in as the first two expansion sides.

She debuted in North Melbourne's inaugural match in 2019 — a 36-point victory over Carlton — and since exemplified much of the Kangaroos' rise to dominance today.

The now 29-year-old had been overlooked for the league's highest accolade, the W Award, more than once.

She was always in the conversation but never an outright favourite.

Yet on Monday night, in North Melbourne's season of total dominance, Riddell narrowly beat Geelong's Georgie Prespakis to be the sole winner of the league's best and fairest.

Ash Riddell beat out Georgie Prespakis for the league's highest individual honour.

It capped off a record-breaking year when she broke her own AFLW disposal record not once, but three times.

Proving how consistent Riddell's overall year was, in many of her dominant matches — such as when she had 45 touches in her side's 68-point win against Sydney in round eight — she didn't poll a single vote.

Under-polling has become somewhat of a theme among North players, particularly with Riddell's teammate and captain Jasmine Garner.

In round 10, Garner didn't collect a single vote, despite having 41 touches and a goal.

ABC Sport will be live blogging the AFLW grand final on Saturday night.

The concern over the pair getting on the stage heading into the night was that they would steal votes off each other, but Riddell highlighted how she wouldn't be the player she was without Garner.

"We just make each other better. We're by-products of each other on the field and we have some really good times off the field as well," Riddell said in her speech.

Ash Riddell (left) and Jasmine Garner have helped each other out during the Kangaroos' rise. (AAP: James Ross)

Watching them together on the field, it's hard to argue against it.

Like Riddell's steady rise, the conversation around the Kangaroos before their 2024 maiden flag win was that they were good, but weren't the best.

They couldn't beat the other "top-four sides" in Brisbane, Adelaide and Melbourne.

It's a cliché, but nevertheless true, to say the Kangaroos just stuck to their systems, put their heads down and kept working.

Now they have a 26-match winning streak, have gone two home-and-away seasons undefeated and will head into their third consecutive grand final on Saturday.

And like Riddell on the biggest awards night for the competition, the Kangaroos will go into the season decider as the favourites, after many years of being in the "maybe this year" conversation.

title: Pub made famous by Crocodile Dundee sells after three years on market
text:
If the Walkabout Creek Hotel's walls could talk, they would have more than 120 years of tales to tell.

For many, the outback pub is famous for its featured role in the 1986 film Crocodile Dundee.

But for locals in the tiny town of McKinlay, just over 200 kilometres from Mount Isa, it is the pub, the bottle-o, the caravan park and the post office.

And now, after being on the market since 2022, it has changed hands.

McKinlay-born Angus Brodie and wife Jo Cranney bought the Walkabout Creek Hotel for an undisclosed figure, settling the deal yesterday.

Prior owners Deb and Frank Wurst put the pub on the market so they could retire, after being at the helm for 11 years.

Angus Brodie has been learning how to manage the bar. (Supplied: Angus Brodie)

From childhood memories to pouring his first beer

Grazier Angus Brodie, 33, grew up in McKinlay, where the hotel is the central hub for the town's 160 residents.

"I have memories running around with all the other kids, sneaking a packet of chips and a soft drink," Mr Brodie said.

"Sometimes we'd take our sleeping bags and have a sleepover until it was time to go home."

The new owner had never poured a beer before last week but is ready for the challenge.

"The first beer I poured, I think there was half a glass of frothy head, and the second beer had absolutely no head at all," he laughed.

"I wasn't off to a real good start, but I promise I've turned things around now."

Jo Cranney and Angus Brodie are graziers in McKinlay. (Supplied: Luke Chaplain)

Ms Cranney, 34, grew up in Goondiwindi but moved to Mount Isa to be a nurse, where the two met.

They now run a cattle property 30 minutes away from the pub with their two children and a baby due in April.

The couple bought the pub to diversify their business and have an alternative income stream when the weather and cattle markets aren't favourable.

"In a drought, people probably drink more beer," Mr Brodie said.

The couple hopes to take a farm-to-table approach, selling their beef at the pub.

"That's one thing we're pretty keen to do, showcase our beef and have that on the menu," Mr Brodie said.

The Walkabout was originally built as The Federal Hotel in 1900.

Pub 'in fantastic condition'

Decorated with memorabilia, the Walkabout Creek Hotel is beloved by locals and tourists alike.

The new owners are not planning to change much and are grateful to the prior owners for keeping it in "fantastic condition".

"It's a credit to Frank and Debbie. They've really looked after it over the 11 years they've been there," Mr Brodie said.

Frank and Debbie Wurst ran the pub in McKinlay for 11 years.

Mr Wurst said he and Debbie would miss the pub when they announced their retirement plans in 2022.

"I'm really going to miss the people out here — there are so many great characters," he said.

" It'll be exciting to see what the next lot do with it — if you're going to buy a pub, may as well make it a famous one. "

40 years of Dundee

In 1986, Crocodile Dundee was the highest-grossing film of all time in Australia.

Built in 1900 and licensed in 1901, the real-world Walkabout Creek Hotel is three times as old as the movie that made it famous, and was originally called the Federation Hotel.

The bar used on the film set was donated to the pub after filming, and is now located out the back in the beer garden.

Australian actor Paul Hogan in a scene from the 1986 film Crocodile Dundee. (Supplied: IMDB, Paramount)

Tourists come from far and wide to snap photos with the movie memorabilia.

Next year, it will be 40 years since the release of Crocodile Dundee, and the new owners plan to mark the occasion.

"We will have to do something, that's for sure," Mr Brodie said.

"It's a crucial part of the identity of the pub, and we love it."

title: Uber Eats and DoorDash strike historic deal on pay 'safety net' and accident insurance
text:
A historic deal could transform Australia's gig economy, with the country's two largest on-demand delivery platforms agreeing to minimum pay rates and providing wide-ranging improvements and protections for riders and drivers.

The agreement struck between the Transport Workers Union (TWU) and Uber Eats and DoorDash followed years of campaigning by workers and the union.

Minimum safety net pay rates would put a floor beneath what have been wildly variable earnings for delivery workers, who have often taken home far less than Australia's minimum wage under current pay arrangements, which see them paid per delivery, not for time worked.

The development represents a substantial win for the TWU, which has argued the lack of minimum conditions has pushed down working standards for employees in industries beyond those it covers.

Uber Eats and DoorDash have previously railed against the imposition of minimum conditions and warned it would massively increase costs for consumers.

"Gig workers have campaigned for years for a better industry and, for the first time in the world, there could soon be a minimum floor that represents a life-changing increase to their pay," Michael Kaine, national secretary of the TWU, said in a joint media statement from the three parties.

" After constructive discussions with Uber Eats and DoorDash, this is a significant step towards a fairer gig economy. "

The deal worked out between the union and the dominant players will now be jointly submitted to the industrial umpire, the Fair Work Commission.

Some of the benefits include:

Dispute resolution processes

Accident insurance paid for by the platforms

The right to be represented by a union

The companies welcomed the deal.

"Delivery workers keep Australia moving, helping busy households and supporting small businesses," said Simon Rossi, vice-president of DoorDash in the Asia Pacific.

" This proposal shows we can work together to lift standards and still enable the flexibility people rely on, under the government's new laws. "

The federal government has made significant changes to workplaces in recent years, including the "right to disconnect" and a positive duty to prevent sexual harassment, meaning businesses have to actively prevent, not passively react, to the issue.

Amazon Flex drivers battling bots and culture of fear to keep their jobs Tech giant Amazon claims to offer convenience to both its customers and its contractors. This is what the drivers behind your packages want you to know.

The gig economy has been an outlier while continuing to grow through an increase in customer demand, the scale of operators and technological innovation.

Companies have resisted regulating delivery workers as staff, and have sought changes to the law to allow them to create quasi-employees.

This deal, if ratified, could become the standard for other forms of gig-based work.

"Uber Eats has long supported sensible and modern reforms that strengthen protections and benefits for delivery people, while maintaining the flexibility that is central to gig work," said Ed Kitchen, managing director for Uber Eats Australia and New Zealand.

" We believe fair standards and flexibility should not be mutually exclusive. "

Recently, Menulog joined the list of failed delivery operators in Australia, with its collapse coming after that of Foodora and Deliveroo.

title: School bus cancellations blindside parents and providers
text:
West Australian Sara Anderson is on the school bus advisory committee for her area but only found out via the media that the route used by her two children would be terminated at the end of the term.

"I rang our bus service provider here locally — they were … just as shocked as we were," she said.

Broomehill, about 300 kilometres south of Perth, is one of four locations where school services have been cancelled for 2026 and will be amalgamated into another route.

How that will work and the effect on student travel time is yet to be announced.

The other services cancelled were in Kojonup in the Great Southern, as well as Tammin and Yuna in the Wheatbelt.

Sara Anderson says access to education can play an important role when people decide where to live. (Supplied: Sara Anderson)

Ms Anderson said her family could cope but the difficulty of having the service restored for others in the future was a concern.

"It all just depends on where the pin lands on the map and nothing else seems to be taken into consideration," she said.

"Yes, numbers fluctuate, but our small towns aren't dying — they're just changing, they're evolving, they're dynamic."

Residents in Kondinin, in the Wheatbelt, spent 10 years lobbying for a dedicated bus service, which returned this year and will continue in 2026.

A state government spokesperson said student numbers were always being monitored and, if demand was there, a service could be reinstated.

Ms Anderson said local input was needed to ensure services met community needs.

"In our case it's much easier to get a bus to Katanning than it is to get to our nearest appropriate school," she said.

"We have children that do sport and socialise in the same town, but have to go to another town for school because of the bus routes."

Jobs on the line, parents stretched

Tammin bus service provider Marc Bell was told at the end of October that his contract was cancelled.

Marc Bell was told last month he no longer had the driving contract. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Chloe Henville)

He said the lack of the service would make it harder to draw young families into the regional town, 180 kilometres east of Perth.

"We've lost a lot of people over the years, and the actual shire is … trying to bring more people in," Mr Bell said.

"With the farmers, [the bus service] would give them confidence in being able to employ married people with children."

He said the service he provided was used by three students and that another was due to join in 2026.

The double amputee said the decision left his own future unclear.

"Personally, I'll lose a substantial amount of money and, having artificial legs, it's not gonna make it easy for me," Mr Bell said.

"I'm not quite sure what I'm going to do yet."

Four school bus routes will not continue in the 2026 school year in regional WA. (Supplied: Sara Anderson)

Since 2020, 20 school bus services have been cancelled and amalgamated into other routes in regional WA, including those recently revealed.

Families are given a conveyance allowance of 57.81c per kilometre to drive their children to school or to get them on other bus routes.

Isolated Children's Parents' Association WA president Jane Cunningham said that was welcome but only went so far.

"It certainly does not cover costs, [but] it contributes," she said.

"Within it, there's other challenges, where parents then need to take the time away from their work to drive their children to and from school, so it can be quite disruptive to business and allowing you to actually be in the workforce."

title: Everton player sent off for slapping teammate during Premier League match
text:
Everton midfielder Idrissa Gueye has been sent off for slapping teammate Michael Keane during the first half of the club's Premier League match against Manchester United.

Gueye and Keane were arguing after the ball was turned over and United's Bruno Fernandes had a shot on goal in the 13th minute at Old Trafford.

The score was 0-0 at the time, before victorious Everton recorded the only goal of the match via Kiernan Dewsbury-Hall in the 29th minute.

The teammates were face-to-face when defender Keane shoved Gueye, who responded with a left-handed slap to Keane's face.

Referee Tony Harrington then showed Gueye a red card.

Idrissa Gueye is restrained by Jordan Pickford as referee Tony Harrington shows a red card. (Getty Images: Carl Recine)

Everton goalkeeper Jordan Pickford and winger Iliman Ndiaye intervened to walk Gueye away.

The Premier League confirmed the decision had been checked and cleared by VAR.

"The referee's call of red card to Gueye for violent conduct was checked and confirmed by VAR — with the action deemed to be a clear strike to the face of Keane," the Premier League Match Centre wrote on X.

Everton manager David Moyes spoke about the incident after the match.

"I thought the referee could maybe have taken a little bit longer to think about it and maybe just gone over and sorted it out," Moyes said.

"Gueye has apologised for the sending off and praised the players after the game in the dressing room."

It is the first time a Premier League player has been sent off for an altercation with a teammate since Stoke City's Ricardo Fuller was dismissed for slapping Andy Griffin during a match at West Ham United in 2008.

Reuters/AP

title: Racetrack no longer has pole position in government's 'Perth Park' project
text:
The WA government's controversial Burswood Park racetrack has had a few names since the project was announced, but its latest is the most deliberate.

Labor touted its 'Motorsport Street Circuit' pitch on the election campaign trail in January, hoping to hold its overwhelming majority with an exciting new project.

Perth likes to look to other capital cities for inspiration — take Elizabeth Quay's similarities to Brisbane's South Bank, which former Liberal Premier Colin Barnett liked to reference — so why not build a racetrack like Melbourne's Albert Park? People will love it.

The only problem was, a loud group didn't.

Artist impression of aerial view of Perth Park (Perth Entertainment and Sporting Precinct) in Burswood. (Supplied: WA government)

By May, the government had seemingly rebranded the project to the 'Perth Entertainment and Sporting Precinct', framing it as a multi-use community hub, rather than a motorsport street circuit.

Now, it's had a second name change to something simpler — 'Perth Park' — although time will tell whether this rebrand will win over critics or be another band-aid for a wound that's bleeding quickly.

Shift in focus

The gripe most critics have had are with the project's former main element — the racetrack.

But this latest rebrand makes sure that's well and truly buried.

On the project's website, all mentions of the multi-use track carefully position the motorsport element as more of an aside.

WA Premier Roger Cook and Minister for Sport and Recreation Rita Saffioti reveal details of 'Perth Park' on Sunday. (ABC News: Lauren Smith)

"For cycling training and competitions, as well as an annual motorsport street circuit event," the website reads.

That's a vastly different focus to the government's original pitch to voters when Premier Roger Cook posed for photos inside a V8 Supercar.

"Today we're announcing that we will transform this park into a world class entertainment precinct," Mr Cook said in January.

"If elected, a WA Labor government will build a Perth street circuit. This is something that people have talked about for years, now it's starting to happen."

Roger Cook sat in a V8 Supercar as the track proposal was announced. (Facebook: Roger Cook)

The Premier said the street circuit would "put WA on the global motorsports map" just like Townsville or the Gold Coast, but a project update over the weekend was not quite so racetrack focused.

"[New released pictures] show our plan for the area which will include a new multi-purpose building which will offer a range of event, function and meeting spaces … our first ever dedicated outdoor amphitheatre venue for up to 12,000 people, a new multi-use track that will support a range of uses including cycling and annual motorsport street circuit events," Mr Cook said on Sunday.

He also tried out the rebranded name on the tongue.

The announcement of the project triggered a backlash from some residents. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

"Where will I see you? I'll see you at Perth Park," he said.

" We'll get off at the Stadium Station and we'll come down here and watch some incredible sports and entertainment events. "

Deputy Premier Rita Saffioti backed him up, steadfast that the project had been clear from the outset.

"We've always outlined from the initial press conference that we held just here, we outlined that there was three components to this project," she said at the site.

"Which included a multi-use track, it included an amphitheatre which … has been something that has been wanted by the music industry."

Fuel to the fire

Rebrand aside, the government would have hoped the project's business case, released over the weekend, would quash criticism given it confirmed two things.

The project's $217 million price tag has stayed the same and the individual racetrack component costs $23 million.

"About a tenth of the total cost is the multi-use racetrack which is for both supercars and cycling, so again some of the claims out there saying $217 million for a racetrack is completely false," Ms Saffioti said.

But for the project's opponents, it added fuel to the fire.

Basil Zempilas has been a vocal critic of the project. (ABC News: Phoebe Pin)

"Do others not see what a miracle this is that … after all of the changes and iterations that apparently the government have been working through, they've still landed on exactly the same number that they announced 10 months ago, $217.5 million," Opposition Leader Basil Zempilas said on Sunday.

The summary, prepared by independent economics firm ACIL Allen, importantly outlined new figures the government could stand by.

Tensions grow as images of Burswood plan released The deputy premier accuses the Town of Victoria Park of lying to ratepayers over the controversial $217 million entertainment and sporting precinct in Burswood.

"People will never be satisfied until their argument wins the day … the economics suggest that Perth Park will deliver a $61 million return to the West Australian economy," Mr Cook said on Monday morning.

The business case might be released, but a looming question mark still remains about a piece of land needed for the project currently in Crown's possession.

Mr Cook said negotiations were "advanced" and "going well" with further costs for the piece of land on top of the $217 million still not anticipated.

Regardless, the government will be hoping its second crack at rebranding this project will stick, or they'll have to get back to the drawing board to think of more names.

title: Nine South West suburbs have median house prices of more than $1 million
text:
Amelia Glass grew up playing with her family dog and swimming in the dam on her parents' property in Margaret River — 270 kilometres south of Perth.

The 20-year-old student said she had always dreamed of returning to live in the town after finishing university.

Amelia Glass grew up in Maragret River and says she chose her degree with a career in the south-west in mind. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Ms Glass feels she is already priced out of her home town with a recent report showing it is one of nine areas in the south-west of WA with a median house price of $1 million.

The report by Cotality revealed one in three housing markets nationwide hit the threshold for the so-called "million-dollar club" with holiday hotspots like Margaret River, Yallingup, Dunsborough and Cowaramup included.

"I always thought Margaret River would be a cheap place to live because of the fact that we're so far from the city and we have got all these new housing developments going in," Ms Glass said.

"But hearing that the price has now gone up even more — it's kind of made the idea of living in Margaret River in the future much more daunting."

Amelia Glass hopes to live out the great Australian dream of home ownership but is concerned rising house prices will put that dream out of reach. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

She said current government assistance schemes were not enough to allow people her age into the housing market.

"It seems very out of reach to afford, especially if I'm going to be living alone as a young woman — that $1 million price tag makes it a challenge," she said.

"When you look back a couple of generations and see how easy it was for our grandparents to buy their own homes.

" People my age with no dependents will find it incredible difficult to buy a home in the future unless they can rely on the bank of mum and dad. "

In 2006 the median house price in Maragret River was just $475,000. (ABC South West: Madigan Landry)

Regional lifestyle comes at a cost

Economist Kaytlin Ezzy from property research company Cotality, said seven-figure median house prices used to be reserved for a small number of especially affluent areas.

"It really started as this prestige club that only a few suburbs across the country were part of," she said.

Julie Fairclough says the market is showing no sign of slowing down. (ABC South West: Jacqueline Lynch)

Ms Ezzy said government assistance schemes did not help new home owners to manage mortgage repayments.

"To buy a million-dollar household, your average household has to spend about 50-55 per cent of their income paying a mortgage," she said.

" For those on the 5 per cent deposit scheme, that jumps up to about 60 per cent, so it does raise the question of affordability for those buyers. "

The coastal hamlet of Yallingup remains WA's most expensive regional market with a median house price of more than $2 million.

Julie Fairclough says it is rare for a home in Dunsborough to be sold for less than $1 million — neighbouring Yallingup boasts a $2 million median house price. (ABC South West: Jacqueline Lynch)

Just 10 minutes down the road in Dunsborough, real estate agent Julie Fairclough said the dream of owning a family home in the town was becoming less of a reality for homegrown locals.

"It's extremely difficult to get a house under $900,000 in Dunsborough now, just a normal, family 3x1 or 4x2 is very difficult," she said.

Development process taking too long

South-west town planner Dane Gaunt said the region was suffering from a wide array of housing roadblocks.

"We've got a planning shortage but we can't attract more planners to the region because they can't find housing," he said.

Mr Gaunt said responsibility for the housing shortage in the region was shared.

"I see a lot of projects get caught up in process and it might be at the state level, at the federal level, at the local government level, or it might be process on the developers side," he said.

Dane Gaunt says the south-west faces challenges with establishing infrastructure and process delays when trying to provide more housing supply to the region. (ABC South West: Jacqueline Lynch)

"In terms of specific barriers — enabling infrastructure is a big one … power infrastructure and sewer infrastructure is massive and causing a lot of delays.

"It's really important to accept everything has to go through a process but it's not process for process's sake."

title: Guardiola 'embarrassed and ashamed' after confronting camera operator
text:
Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola says he is "embarrassed and ashamed" after a confrontation with a camera operator following his side's Premier League defeat at Newcastle United.

Guardiola was furious at several refereeing decisions during the 2-1 loss at St James' Park on Sunday AEDT and appeared to take out his frustration on a pitch-side TV camera operator after the final whistle.

Speaking ahead of City's Champions League home match with Bayer Leverkusen on Tuesday AEDT, Guardiola said: "I feel embarrassed and ashamed when I see it. I don't like it.

"I apologise to the cameraman. I am who I am. Even with 1,000 games I am not a perfect person and I make mistakes. I defend my team and my club."

Pep Guardiola says he is ashamed of his behaviour. (Getty Images/sportsphoto: Ed Sykes)

City's defeat left the club seven points behind leaders Arsenal in the Premier League.

But Guardiola's team will have an immediate chance to shrug off any hangover as they take on Leverkusen.

It will be Guardiola's 100th Champions League match as City manager.

"I realise I'm getting old. It's good. It means every season we've been there," Guardiola said.

"It's a huge competition. It's special for the players.

"To challenge yourself with the best teams in Europe is incredible, a huge experience. For the club, in terms of reputation, prestige and financial issues, it's massively important."

City is fourth in the Champions League table after three wins and a draw.

A victory at home to 21st-placed Leverkusen would leave City in a strong position to claim a top-eight position and avoid the necessity of a play-off to reach the knockout rounds.

Reuters

title: Roof blown off house, schools closed as severe weather lashes south-east Qld
text:
About 90,000 households remain without power and 11 state schools are closed after giant hailstones, destructive winds and intense lightning lashed south-east Queensland, with more extreme weather on the way.

Education Minister John-Paul Langbroek said the schools had been closed due to storm damage, including several at Bribie Island.

"This damage is similar to the types of things that we know happens in these storm events, just as we had with ex-tropical cyclone Alfred," he said.

Loading...

Another 47 schools were dealing with "significant IT issues", but Mr Langbroek said they remained open.

The worst power outages were in Moreton Bay, where about 51,000 customers lost power.

Approximately 13,000 homes were affected on the Sunshine Coast, with a further 9,000 in Noosa, 7,000 in Ipswich, 5,000 in Gympie, and around 1,700 in Brisbane.

Fierce winds brought down trees, destroying a pergola at one property in the coastal suburb of Margate. (Supplied: Genevieve Lojek)

Energex recorded 880,000 lightning strikes, alongside wind gusts over 100 kilometres per hour.

Spokesperson Justin Coomber said crews worked through the night to restore the network, with new crews deployed to help with restoration efforts.

"We're looking at about 600 powerlines down now, so that's a good indication of how much work has been done," he said.

"When you look at it, it's not just the powerlines. There have been broken power poles, and all of the equipment that is up on the equipment as well."

Mitchelton residents say they found hail the size of their hand. (Supplied: Kayleen Gordon)

Intense storm cells swept through the region yesterday afternoon, bringing heavy rain, strong winds and giant hail up to 14 centimetres in size.

A fuel bowser was torn from its mount and blown onto a car at an Ipswich service station. (Supplied: Ipswich Metal Recycling )

Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) senior forecaster Shane Kennedy said the largest recorded was in Chandler, south-east of Brisbane's CBD.

"Certainly lots of places picked up large hail, in the five to 10 centimetre range," he said.

Hail broke a window in the Brisbane suburb of Keperra. (Supplied)

Areas from the Gold Coast to the Sunshine Coast were hit, and about 161,000 properties lost power.

Mr Kennedy said rainfall totals of up to 70 millimetres were recorded in some areas.

Loading...

" Moreton Island had 79, that was the highest, but also Frank Sleeman Park at Boondall had 77 millimetres, which is just north of Brisbane. "

Giant hail battered the south-east. (Supplied: Kayleen Gordon)

Two people were evacuated from their Loganlea home after the roof blew off, and many properties on Bribie Island were also damaged.

The SES responded to more than 2,000 calls for help, while flights and train services were disrupted.

The storm downed trees at Coolum on the Sunshine Coast. (ABC News: Jessica Ross)

North coast regional commander Jason Pascoe said the focus was on debris, allowing residents to come and go from their properties.

"We could see large trees across the roadways, damage to vehicles across roofs," he said.

Loading...

More thunderstorms on the way

Mr Kennedy said conditions would warm up throughout the day, with more severe thunderstorms expected across the south-east.

More storms predicted amid 'very unsettled' Queensland weather Storm-battered south-east Queensland is on alert again today as instability grips the state.

"Expecting to get up around the mid 30s again … around 33 [degrees] in the city, 37 in the west," he said.

"We will have another round of thunderstorms unfortunately.

"Quite likely to see severe thunderstorms through the south-east later today."

The SES is urging residents to clear gutters and secure loose items.

"Any materials that can be blown around, any outdoor furniture, bring them inside," Mr Pascoe said.

"It's still important for us to take the opportunity to make sure our homes are properly prepared."

title: Live: Bendigo Bank shares dive on money laundering worries, ASX flat
text:
Earlier this morning, the TWU, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations Amanda Rishworth and delivery drivers fronted a press conference in Canberra.

Secretary of the peak body of Australian unions, Sally McManus, gave a bit of a potted history of the gig economy as she paid tribute to the Transport Workers Union and workers in gaining the new protections.

"Aussie unions have pulled off a world first. This is the first time in the world that gig riders, delivery riders, have got minimum conditions and are now treated and respected as they should be. And Australian unions were never gonna leave behind these workers. " "We knew when they started joining their union, the TWU, the poverty wages they were on and how much they were being pushed to complete orders. "Unfortunately, throughout this eight-year fight, we've seen some workers be killed because they were pushed so hard by the algorithm to deliver orders quickly in our big cities and forced to drive (in) dangerous conditions. And you know, it's in their memory too, that these laws are here."

Sadly, the number of delivery riders killed in recent years is too numerous to list, but the ABC has covered many including, Burak Dogan, Dede Fredy and Xiaojun Chen.

"We would never accept the fact that some workers in our country had less rights than workers did a hundred years ago. "We worked with the Labor government to get new laws in place that gave them the legal minimums but new laws are one thing, putting them in action is another thing and that's due to the work of the TWU and the members who have negotiated with these huge multinationals UberEats and DoorDash to put in place minimum standards which are going to lead quite frankly, to very significant pay increases for these workers as well as protection in terms of insurance for them and to make sure that they have basic rights that other workers have to be properly consulted about how their work happens.

The laws also put in protections against summary dismissal. In standard employment, there are protections (as well as the ability for employers to boot staff doing egregious and illegal things). Now, increased job security for workers taking on the internet giants.

title: Thousands of women missing out on 'gold standard' antenatal care
text:
Geelong mother Rachel Harkin knew she wanted continuity of care for her first pregnancy.

At 28 weeks pregnant, she felt lucky to score a place in Barwon Health's free Midwifery Group Practice (MGP) program, which offers women the same midwife to care for them during pregnancy, birth and postpartum.

"It was such an empowering experience and I feel so fortunate that I can look back on my daughter Amelia's birth with really fond memories," she said.

Serena Pellizzeri says demand for the program is growing. (ABC News: Jonathon Kendall)

The program's coordinator and midwife, Serena Pellizzeri, is fast to list the benefits of that one-on-one care.

"Better birth outcomes, better experiences, better continuity, and we know it creates great workforce sustainability as well for our midwives, and it's actually cost-effective," she said.

The program differs from some other public programs that offer a team of rotating midwives or shared care with doctors.

But accessing the popular MGP program can be tough due to demand, eligibility and limited midwife staffing.

Some pregnant women turn to private midwives for continuity of care. (ABC News: Erin Somerville)

The ABC contacted 69 publicly funded Victorian hospitals and health services, with just 17 confirming that they offered MGP or primary midwife models of care, while six did not respond.

Of those services that offered these programs, they generally catered to less than 20 per cent of births.

"We have recognised how popular the program is and we are currently under an expansion," said Ms Pellizzeri, whose program is also facing pressure from fast population growth.

Turning to private care

One regional Victorian private midwife said it was unfair that many pregnant women, particularly in regional areas, were unable to access maternity care for free.

Lindsay Coward wants more women to be able to access free antenatal care. (ABC News: Erin Somerville)

Midwife Lindsay Coward said many women who could not access her region's unique local Maternity Antenatal Postnatal program, which caters to about 300 of the 1,500 annual births, paid for a private midwife, while there were increasingly fewer local GPs or obstetricians offering care.

Ms Coward, who works privately, said she would like more regional women to have less restricted access to free and comprehensive antenatal care.

"The aim would be that women would have the first option to be able to be seen freely, and if they chose to see someone privately that would be at their discretion, not because they had no other options," she said.

Lindsay Coward checks patient Tiarne Sainty's blood pressure. (ABC News: Erin Somerville)

She said it was not uncommon for some women who were unable to access public maternity services to miss antenatal appointments due to financial pressure.

"We really would want to see women at all of the key markers as opposed to when they feel they can afford it," Ms Coward said.

She said some private midwives were pushing for hospital admitting rights to help plug the gap and improve continuity of care.

Tiarne Sainty attends a private midwife appointment. (ABC News: Erin Somerville)

Wodonga resident Tiarne Sainty chose to use a private midwife and birth in her local public hospital, with continuity of care playing an important role in that decision, even though she was unable to access her private midwife during labour.

"I think pregnancy and childbirth is a huge journey and it's nice to get that same friendly face every appointment that really understands and gets to know you and your baby," she said.

Strengthening personalised care

The Victorian government last year announced the establishment of the Victorian Maternity Taskforce to implement best models of care, particularly in rural and regional areas.

The maternity taskforce has made recommendations to improve care. (ABC News: Lisa Mctiernan)

The taskforce this month released a report with nine key recommendations to improve access, choice, and outcomes for women and babies, including the development of personalised care that prioritised choice and experience for women.

Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation Victoria branch assistant secretary, Nicole Allen, said there were many reports backing the MGP program and the continuity of care it offered as being "gold standard", and it should be more accessible.

"We know that women want these services and currently in Victoria they only offer up to about 10 per cent of the model of care in the public health system, and in regional services that's much less of course because they're more concentrated in metro," she said.

Nicole Allen says reports show the benefits of the MGP program. (ABC News: Tara Whitchurch)

"I think while there may not need to be more money funded into them, there needs to be more funnelling into the MGP stream because we can develop them at a relatively low cost. They're actually quite cost efficient."

The Victorian government said it planned to work to strengthen MGP programs based on the taskforce's recommendations.

"We continue to see strong demand for Midwifery Group Practice across Victoria — it's why we're investing $270 million to grow our nurse and midwife workforce and invest in a range of maternity care initiatives," a Victorian government spokesperson said.

title: Australia news LIVE: Government moves censure motion against Pauline Hanson; Senators slam government’s secret Nauru deal
text:
Environment Minister Murray Watt has returned serve to Opposition Leader Sussan Ley, after she accused him of “mismanaging” negotiations over his proposed reforms to national nature laws.

Ley said Watt was merely seeking “a political fix” and not acting in the national interest.

Watt dismissed Ley’s claim, claimed the opposition was unable to move past its ructions over Ley’s leadership and said multiple negotiators had approached him claiming to speak for the Coalition.

Environment Minister Murray Watt. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen

“The idea that Sussan Ley wants to accuse people of mismanagement is laughable.

“The problem with negotiations with the Coalition all along is they haven’t been able to focus on what they want, because they are focusing on their internals. We are now at a point where we have multiple people from the coalition seeking to negotiate with me, rather than one.

“I have got multiple people coming to me saying they are negotiating for the Coalition.”

Watt said his reforms would deliver for the environment and business.

title: Hazlewood back bowling as Cummins trains with a pink ball
text:
Australia have received a major boost ahead of the second Ashes Test, with fast bowler Josh Hazlewood spotted bowling for the first time since injuring his hamstring in a Sheffield Shield match.

A day after coach Andrew McDonald dismissed speculation Hazlewood would miss the entire series, the 34-year-old was back on deck at Cricket NSW headquarters in Sydney on Tuesday morning.

Josh Hazlewood bowls at Cricket NSW headquarters on Tuesday. Credit: Getty Images

Hazlewood was joined by regular Test captain Pat Cummins, who bowled with a pink ball - a telling clue ahead of next week’s day-night Test in Brisbane, beginning December 4.

Hazlewood failed to finish the Blues’ most recent Sheffield Shield match against Victoria after pulling up with a hamstring issue.
